cards.title: Introduction to JavaScript
cards.question: What is a closure in JavaScript?
cards.answer: A closure is the combination of a function bundled together (enclosed) with references to its surrounding state (the lexical environment).

cards.title: React State Management
cards.question: What is the difference between props and state in React?
cards.answer: Props (short for properties) are read-only and passed down from parent to child components. State is managed within a component and can change over time.

cards.title: CSS Flexbox
cards.question: How do you center an item horizontally and vertically using Flexbox?
cards.answer: Set the parent container to `display: flex;`, `justify-content: center;` (for horizontal centering), and `align-items: center;` (for vertical centering).

cards.title: Node.js Basics
cards.question: What is the Node.js event loop?
cards.answer: The event loop allows Node.js to perform non-blocking I/O operations — despite the fact that JavaScript is single-threaded — by offloading operations to the system kernel whenever possible.

cards.title: TypeScript Types
cards.question: What is an interface in TypeScript?
cards.answer: An interface in TypeScript is a way to define a contract for an object's shape. It specifies the names and types of properties an object should have.

cards.title: REST API Principles
cards.question: What does idempotent mean in the context of HTTP methods?
cards.answer: An HTTP method is idempotent if an identical request can be made once or several times in a row with the same effect while leaving the server in the same state. GET, PUT, DELETE are idempotent.
